item.title: 2021 & early 2022 news
item.description: Some good news from the past and starting year: Yohan Sahraoui, Laure Carassou and researchers from Biogeco have published in Land Use Planning the results of their investigations regarding how changes in land use in the Bordeaux conurbation will affect ecological connectivity. They have coupled a spatial network model of ecological connectivity to a participatory modelling approach from social sciences. By doing so, they uncovered that the anticipated impacts on ecological connectivity of urban sprawl and densification are unfortunately quite similar to the worst scenarios for future urban development (!

item.title: Estimating survival rates of Gyrfalcons in Iceland
item.description: The annual probability of survival of the average adult individual is a critical parameter for demographic projections of long-lived animal populations. Indeed, small changes to this adult survival rate can yield large changes in the rate of population growth or decline. Yet this parameter was still unknown for the Gyrfalcon, an iconic raptor living in boreal and arctic ecosystems. In a recent PeerJ article1, Ólafur K. Nielsen and I estimate adult as well as juvenile survival rates for the Icelandic population of gyrfalcons.

item.title: Estimation des taux de survie des faucons gerfauts en Islande
item.description: La probabilité annuelle de survie de l’individu adulte moyen est un paramètre critique pour les projections démographiques des populations animales longévives. item.title: Postdoctoral position in statistical ecology
item.description: I have a new postdoc position opening (details in linked pdf) on improving dynamic models including interactions within and between species, notably their identifiability properties, by combining different kinds of data. I would be open to a variety of candidate profiles, ranging from somebody with statistical or probability background that would focus on mathematical aspects of identifiability, to somebody more interested in fitting dynamic models to data. Don’t hesitate to contact me for an informal chat if you may be interested.

item.title: 2020 News
item.description: Well, this has been a difficult year for everybody and we certainly hope that the end of 2020 has less surprises to offer… That said, amidst the covid-19 chaos, some pieces of good news: Alix started a new position at the French committee for the IUCN this spring. She’s working on the Ecosystem Red List. Congratulations Alix! Gaël Bardon, who studied with Frederic how stage/age structure can help foster coexistence for his MSc “Mathématiques du Vivant” (Polytechnique & AgroParisTech), has successfully defended his thesis.

item.title: 2019 News
item.description: After the holiday break, most of us have good news to share. Yohan just started his tenured lecturer position at University Paris I Sorbonne (UMR 8586 - Prodig). Congratulations Yohan! Coralie has officially started her PhD thesis in phytoplankton dynamics and coexistence in October. She also teaches modeling of dynamic systems and statistics for biology and bioinformatics. Alix extends a bit her current position with us until the end of 2019; she will work with us on the project BiodiverCité on urban pollinators.

item.title: Opportunities
item.description: We host internships for MSc. students (one per year so far) - contact us if interested to work with us, here are our research themes. Every year, Bordeaux’s Idex has a call for postdoctorate fellowships, these will allow to develop your own research project in collaboration with the group. There is also a visiting scholars programme.

item.title: Back from SFEcologie 2018
item.description: We just came back from SFEcologie 2018 – a great conference in Rennes! Alix presented her latest work on seasonal dynamic food webs; Coralie had a poster on diversity maintenance in (also seasonal) theoretical competitive communities, and myself a presentation of our empirical analyses of phytoplankton community dynamics. I really enjoyed Teja Tscharnkte’s plenary on integrating biodiversity services in agriculture. Teja Tscharntke explains why pollinator diversity is crucial to pollination at #sfe2018 pic.

item.title: Spring 2018 news
item.description: Some highlights from the last few months: April Alix and Frederic were in Clermont-Ferrand at Irstea April 10-12 for the Temporal Network working group meeting of the GDR TheoMoDive. We enjoyed good team spirit and discovered a nice new brew (thanks Franck Jabot for organizing!). Frederic gave a presentation in the Biostatistics seminar at ISPED / Bordeaux Population Health centre on the 23rd: “Inferring interactions between species using time series of population counts and multivariate autoregressive models”.
